fol.192r
Novem
b
1591 33 Eli
z
Netherlands
It seemes this Letter was never sent. see back side
w
ch
seemes to bee S
r
Thomas Bodleys own hand.
Having lately understoode, aswell by those letters w
ch
yow have written
to the states, and to yo
r
frindes in these countreis, as by divers other
meanes of assured intelligence, that yow determine very shortly to ad-
dresse yo
r
selves to the forsaide
states
and in the name of the
Empero
rs
Ma
tie
to motion some agreement between them and the Spaniard,
I have thought it very requisit for discharge of my dewtie to my
Souveraigne lady and mistresse the
Q. Ma
tie
of
England,
who hath
bin pleased to honour me, w
t
the place of her Counsailo
r
in this
Co
u
cel
of state
, and for those principal respects, w
ch
I beare in all humilitie
to the Empero
rs
Ma
tie
between whom and my Souveraigne all offices
of amitie have bin alwaies intertened, to prevent yo
r
comming hither
w
t
such advise as this place, and my function will affourd.
It is ten moneths agoe
at
e states of these countreis, upon advertisment
receaved of yo
r
purposed voiage then, to the like effect as nowe, for the
advancement of a peace, directed presently their letters, both to the
Empero
rs
Ma
tie
and to certaine Princes of the Empire, to the end they
should surcease from poursuing that intent; for that it tended altoge-
ther, as was effectually declared, to the ruine of their state, and to
e
Enemies sole advantage. It was hoped therupon that the reasons
then alleaged, w
ch
made a plaine demonstration of many daungerous
inconveniences, that were like to growe upon it, had dissuaded his Ma
tie
from following his designe. But forasmuche as that hope is altogether
frustrat, to the exceeding great griefe of the foresaide states, and of
as many heere, or wheresoever as are ether embarked in the self same
cause, or perfitly acquainted w
t
the state of their affaires, I doubt not
but
at they of themselves will be as carefull, as is possible, to forecast
the very woorst, that they may not be surprised by the glavering offers
of the Enemie. Nevertheles for the readier prevention of all that
may happen, and for the better acquitting of my charge and duty
to my Souveraigne, I am to signifie more unto yow, concerning this
treaty w
ch
yow purpose to negotiat, then hath bin happely expressed
in any letter of the states, or otherwise imparted to the Emperors
Ma
tie
and to yow. What it was that moved the Q. Ma
tie
of England, to undertake the protection and defence of these Provinces,
fol.192v
November 1591
I thinke there is no doubt, but that
e Empero
rs
Ma
tie
doth knowe sufficiently
and according to his wisdome doth approve her proceeding. For she hath
not dealt in secret and covertly, but proceeded w
t
all integritie, and by
publicke declaration, in w
ch
her reasons are proposed to the censure
of all the worlde. But what passed in accorde between her Ma
tie
and this people, and in what conditions ether partie is subject unto
other, that is it w
ch
I suppose is wholy unknowen to
e Empero
rs
Ma
tie
and to yow, or not so knowen in every point, as hath bin solemnely by
them, and reciprocally contracted. It may therfore please yow
to be informed, that among other articles and couvenants it is a spe-
cial point agreed, that nether the General nor Particular states
of these provinces, shall enter into treaty w
t
the common Enemie
e Spaniard, nor w
t
any Prince or Potentat in his behalf, w
t
out
e
privitie and assent of the Q. Ma
tie
of England. And to as many as
are heere of her Ma
tie
ministers, be they Gouvernors of townes, com-
maunders in the feelde, or other officers of trust, there is nothing re-
commended more precisely to their charge, nor more effectually
sett downe in the othe w
ch
they have taken to their Souvraigne and
this contrey, then
at they shall observe, and cause to be observed to their
uttermost endevo
r
, the forsaide article of the Treaty. By
vertue wherof I doe declare by these presents, and notifie unto yow,
that wee are all of us determined to discharge the services of credit
committed heere
u
to us. And though wee knowe there is no doubt,
but that the states of these contreis doe finde their owne prospe-
ritie, and can see the afflicted state of those Provinces and towns,
that are not of
e union: for w
ch
it is to be presumed, that they will
not disesteeme,
or not
but
sufficiently esteeme those extraordinary graces,
w
t
w
ch
God hath so often, and nowe so very lately, blessed their ex-
ploites: but rather will goe forewarde w
t
a greater courrage aga
i
st
the Enemie, both assaulting him by force, and impeaching his un-
just
a
d fraudulent designes. Nevertheles, as if wee knewe
not that intention of the foresaide states, we are thus muche of
o
r
selves to signifie from hens, that unles yow come autorised to this
treaty of peace w
t
the allowance and warrant of the Q. o
r
Mistresse
fol.193r
November 1591
we must all in general, and every one in particular stand against yow, not
only w
t
good arguments of reason and persuasion, but w
t
all the meanes
at
we can make, by any violence or force to disturbe yo
r
attempts: and
at
w
t
out attending or expecting w
at
the Contrey shall resolve. This
message, I knowe, may seeme unto yow straunge, considering that
e
intention of the Emperor tendeth onely to a Concorde, w
ch
is a mat
ter well worthy of his wisdome and puissance, and a thing to be
embraced of every good Christian. But suche is the bonde
of o
r
alleageance to o
r
Souveraigne, the importance of o
r
othes in
respect of the Contract, and o
r
duties, in general to the cause of
these contreis, that w
t
out o
r
Princes dispensation, we may not swarve
from this course, w
ch
I have signified heere unto yowe. Nevertheles,
to say somewhat to the mater, for w
ch
yo
r
comming is intended, albeit
it is not my principal purpose, nor a subject to be handled in so
short a letter, yet
e cause being general and yow indifferently
affected, to make a fruitfull composition, and that w
t
out any pre-
judice to one side or other, upon this oportunitie of writing unto
yow, I hope yow will vouchesafe to consider upon the growndes, for
w
ch
this people will refuse to come in treaty w
t
e Spaniard.
First they say, It is certaine, whatseover is averred by any to the
contrary, that
e
King of Spaines
disposition is wholy opposit to peace.
And this is proved apparantly by a common observation, w
ch
is in
every mans discourse, that there is noe warre at this day in any part
of Christendome but is directly or indirectly sturred and maintained
by the K. of Spaine. What example can be plainer, then his present
partaking in the kingdome of
France?
where w
t
out a just occasi-
on
or
pretext of just occasion, he endevoureth to depose the right ow-
ner from his scepter, and all under collo
r
of zele and divotion to
e
Romishe religion. And if that be all his cause, as his pretence is
no other, would the Emperors Ma
tie
have this people to imagine,
that the kinge of Spaine can be pleased, to permitte unto them,
over whome he clameth a right and absolut autoritie the use of
at
religion for the extirpation wherof he poursueth a forraine Prince
w
t
all
e actes of hostilitie, that he can possibly practise? His purpose
fol.193v
November 1591
is too manifest: he mindes to make holy day w
t
e states of these contreis, till his
maters in France succeede to his minde, and then his hope is, undoubtedly,
that not onely these
Provinces united
, but England and
Scotland,
and
every part of
Germany,
or of any other contrey, that is different from
him in religion, or disjoined in faction, shall accept of suche lawes as he for
his benefit shall prescribe unto them. But let it be admitted,
that his desire to be at peace, is in deede so sincere, as all men knowe
it is dissembled, It is not integrum no more to the people of this contrey,
to condiscend to his demaunde. For their obedience unto him was reno
u
-
ced long agoe, as to a most cruel and unaturall Tyranne: for w
ch
they so-
lemnly proceeded to a publicke Abjuration, by a special forme of wordes:
w
ch
not onely the Magistrats and officers of every towne but every one
in a manner of the meanest of the people hath vowed to observe. And
their vowes to that effect have bin continually confirmed, w
t
as many let-
ters and bookes, and publicke Actes, as have bin published ever sins.
Besides as I have shewed, they are bounde by a special league to her Ma
tie
of England, the onely Prince in Christendome that hath protected their
estate w
t
the daunger of her owne, not to deale in any motion for accord-
ing w
t
the Enemie, w
t
out her notice and avowe. And for her better
assurance, as well of that as of other conditions, they have put in to her
custody in lieu of caution and pledges, such places for townes, as there
are not any belonginge to the states of these contreis of greater import
a
ce
Whiche if her Ma
tie
should convert to their uttermost annoiance, pro-
voked therunto by the infraction of their pactes, no doubt their forces are
so slender, that their present florishing state would quickly come to
ruine. There is also this to be considered, that seing the
Frenche King
is notoriously wronged by
e Spaniardes oppression, and is lincked to this
nation in the qualitie of his cause, and they have hitherto assisted him
w
t
suche reliefe as their state is able to affourde, it can not any way
concurre w
t
e honor of their actions, besides the multitude of perils
to w
ch
they may be subejct, to assent to any peace, w
t
out his special ap-
probation. But to suppose, if yow please, that they may, if
they list, growe in amitie w
t
the Enemie and may revoke w
at
soever they
formerly done, or contracted to the contrary, and that w
t
out any prejudice
to themselves or to their neighbo
rs
, yet this were nothing to these contreis,
to make them hearcken to a peace. For not onely the better sort heere,
and such
vid. supra fol. 190
fol.190r
November 1591
vid infra, fol.192
and suche as are most conversant in the affaires of their gouvernment but every
simple person of vulgar understanding can lay before you many reasons and
can make it evident by proofes that are familiar to all the worlde, that there
can be no Assurance in any peace w
t
e Spaniard. They have alwaies obser-
ved, and doe observe every day by their owne experience, and by the examples
of others, by
e letters of advise, w
ch
they have taken of the kinge and by all
his proceedinges w
t
them and w
t
others, that all his promises and proposals
are captious and counterfaict, tending onely to entrappe and to gaine a littel
time, that by abusing their credulitie, he may watche a fitte occasion to
be revenged upon them. This they have tried in former times by the trea-
cherous Treaties of
Breda,
of Marche in Famine and of
Collen,
of w
ch
and other like the memorie w
t
them is so freshe, and the dommages so great
w
ch
they have sustened by
e losse of divers townes and Provinces, and by the
daungerous alterations, w
ch
the Enemie w
t
his cunning sette a foote among
the Commons, as if they trust him any more, they might seeme to be be-
refte of all goode use of common sense. But besides the examples among
themselves, they sawe the other day in his dealing w
t
England a most
palpable patterne of Spanishe falshoode and deceat. For even then, and
at the same instant, that his ministers were emploied to persuade her Ma
tie
to a peace, by proposing unto her very plausible conditions, he armed a Navy
to the seas, w
ch
in his Lucifers pride he termed Invincible, to make a conquest
of her kingdome. But howe that wickednes was punished by
e mightie
hand of God, it is knowen er this to all the worlde, and it will be recorded to
all posteritie. Againe by Gods good providence they have had the hap-
pines of late to intercept certaine letters subscribed w
t
the Kinges owne hande
and addressed to
Don Guillaume de S
t
Clement
his owne Ambassador in
the Emperors court, by w
ch
it doth appeare, that howsoever his offers are outwardly
disguised w
t
the cloake of Pacification, the secret drift of his hearte, and his
inward intention is full of malice and imposture. In effect all his actions
are directed by that most unchristian, and barbarous maxime, That w
t
an Hereticke there is no faith to be observed. Whiche infamous point
of doctrine was most wickedly devised by the
Pope
and Popishe Princes, to
serve their wordly turnes: distrusting as it seemeth the truth of their owne
Religion, As if God were not able, their cause being just, (as they are per-
suaded) and their party being greater by many multitudes of people, to
uphold their estate w
t
out
e breache of common faith. But if this be
so maintened against Heretickes in general, w
at
application will be made
fol.190v
November 1591
by the king and his favourers against the Heretickes of this contrey? W
ch
have taken armes against him, have renounced his religion, solemnly deposed
him by way of Abjuration, and delivered unto others the possession of his
landes. It is certaine, in conclusion, howsoever all his offers are masqued
w
t
faire promises, and sette out unto the shewe, they are inwardly full of
guile, and of a daungerous double meaning. But thankes be to God
the people of these Provinces have a special insight in their owne estate,
and give a singular judgement of
e nature of these motives of the Em-
pero
rs
Ma
tie
. They have felt so often the smarte of those roddes of the
Spanishe Pacifications that they can rectefie their courses by their
owne experience, wherby they knowe, as I have signified, That first
the Kinge hath no willingnes to estbalishe any peace: secondly that
it is not in their power to admitte any treaty: and thirdly that they
can have no securitie by any composition. And yet againe to presuppose
that the Kinges intention were entire and unfained, that the contrey
heere were at libertie to make their owne peace, and that
e Kinges
proceedinges had given no occasion to incurre so great suspicion, yet to
returne againe to that w
ch
is the cheifest occasion of my writinge
u
to
you, Unles yow shewe for yo
r
comming the liking and permission of her
Ma
tie
my Souveraigne, I must needes forwarne yow as before, That
as many of us as are heere of her Ma
ties
subjectes, doe resolve to w
t
stand
yow, as perturbers of the amitie between her and the contrey. And
in
at respect every man in his charge will accomplishe the duties of
his faith and obedience, by forcing yow from hens. And though
I speake in this sorte very plainely and roundly, beinge bounde therunto
by mine othe and alleageance, yet I rest out of doubt, that yo
r
singular
wisdeomes will expounde my meaning to the best, an d being somuche
preadvertised of
e strict alliance and contract between her Ma
tie
and
these contreis, will forbeare upon it to goe forward w
t
yo
r
voiage intended.
But if it fall out so in truthe, as in semblance is pretended, that the
Kinge of Spaine ether weried w
t
his warres, or reduced to extremitie,
or findinge in continuance that God doth not prosper his dissembled
proceedinges, shall be willing now at lenght to speake as he thinketh,
and to stipulat a firme and a durable peace, there is no other kinde of
meanes to effect his purpose, but by causing the like proffers of peace,
as are made to these Provinces, to be presented in like sorte to her Ma
tie
of England
fol.191r
November 1591
to the Kinge in France, and to as many other Princes as sitte complaininge
at the helme of one common cause, and runne in danger to be drowned
in the bottomlesse gulf of the Spanishe Ambition. To this there
is no doubt but
e Kinge will condiscend, if his minde and meaning be
cleere and upright, and this is it w
ch
her Ma
tie
my Souveraigne, the
states of these contreis, and every forraine Potentat will most wil-
lingly helpe forewarde, w
t
all the meanes of assistaunce that they can
minister unto him.
fol.191v
Project of a l
re
w
ch
I purposed to send to
e Empero
rs
Ambas
s
Thomas Bodley Ambassador w
th
the States of Holland
to the
the Coppy of his Lettere writen to the Emperores Ambassadores, November 1591 33 Eli
z
